articles.headline: A Bet on a Brazilian Brewery Pays Off for 3 Investors
articles.snippet: When Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Telles bought Companhia Cervejaria Brahma in 1989, what the three investment bankers got for their $50 million was a traditional, but somewhat tired Brazilian brewery that barely dripped ...
articles.abstract: When Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Telles bought Companhia Cervejaria Brahma in 1989, what the three investment bankers got for their $50 million was a traditional, but somewhat tired Brazilian brewery that barely dripped dividends.    On Wednesday, the trio agreed to swap their controlling stake in AmBev, the top Brazilian top brewer that grew from Brahma, to Belgium's Interbrew in a complex equity deal that would give them a major stake in what would be the world's largest beermaker by volume and -- according to people close to the deal -- would give them nearly $3 billion in Interbrew shares. The three will have a right to name four board members of the new company, as will Interbrew.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Telles bought Companhia Cervejaria Brahma in 1989, what the three investment bankers got for their $50 million was a traditional, but somewhat tired Brazilian brewery that barely dripped dividends.

articles.headline: Chief Executives Planning to Hire Outnumber Those Who Foresee Cuts
articles.snippet: Chief executives of the nation's largest companies say they are finally ready to begin hiring again.    For the first time in at least a year and a half, more executives plan to increase employment in the United States over the next six months tha...
articles.abstract: Chief executives of the nation's largest companies say they are finally ready to begin hiring again.    For the first time in at least a year and a half, more executives plan to increase employment in the United States over the next six months than plan to cut jobs, according to a survey released yesterday by the Business Roundtable, a lobbying group. Thirty-three percent of the executives said they would add jobs, up from just 12 percent in October, while 22 percent said they would reduce the number of employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chief executives of the nation's largest companies say they are finally ready to begin hiring again.

articles.headline: Corporate Democracy and the Power to Embarrass
articles.snippet: Corporate democracy in America has most often been a lot like Soviet democracy: the votes didn't really matter, because only one candidate was on the ballot and was assured of winning, whatever the voters thought.    In a sense, the vote against M...
articles.abstract: Corporate democracy in America has most often been a lot like Soviet democracy: the votes didn't really matter, because only one candidate was on the ballot and was assured of winning, whatever the voters thought.    In a sense, the vote against Michael D. Eisner yesterday falls into that category. The preliminary count shows that Mr. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive of Disney, had 43 percent of the votes withheld from him in his re-election as director. But he still won, picking up the support of 57 percent of those who voted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate democracy in America has most often been a lot like Soviet democracy: the votes didn't really matter, because only one candidate was on the ballot and was assured of winning, whatever the voters thought.

articles.headline: LVMH Announces A 30% Increase In Income for Year
articles.snippet: Buoyed by record margins for its star leather goods and fashion brand, Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton on Wednesday announced a 30 percent jump in its net income for 2003.     Net income rose to 723 million euros, or $884 million, in 2003, the company...
articles.abstract: Buoyed by record margins for its star leather goods and fashion brand, Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton on Wednesday announced a 30 percent jump in its net income for 2003.     Net income rose to 723 million euros, or $884 million, in 2003, the company said in a statement. Net sales for the year fell 6 percent to 11.96 billion euros, though using a comparable structure and exchange rates, sales would have risen 4 percent, the company said. Operating income was up 9 percent, to 2.18 billion euros.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buoyed by record margins for its star leather goods and fashion brand, Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton on Wednesday announced a 30 percent jump in its net income for 2003.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Hotel Company's Profit Falls
articles.snippet: The hotel and leisure company Accor reported a 37 percent decline in net income for 2003 as the global economic slowdown, the war in Iraq, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and foreign exchange fluctuations hurt results. The compan...
articles.abstract: The hotel and leisure company Accor reported a 37 percent decline in net income for 2003 as the global economic slowdown, the war in Iraq, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and foreign exchange fluctuations hurt results. The company said it earned 270 million euros ($329 million) last year, down from 430 million euros in 2002 and below the 281 million euros expected by analysts. The company said, however, that it had seen signs of recovery in the second half of the year, particularly in the United States, Britain and Germany. The company, which is based in Paris, said it cut its debt by 370 million euros and maintained its dividend; and its share price rose 3 percent.

articles.abstract: The jury in the Martha Stewart trial completed its first day of deliberations yesterday after making several requests for transcript excerpts, charts and phone logs, most of them focused on Dec. 27, 2001, the day she sold nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems.    The jury of eight women and four men, which was dispatched to deliberate shortly before noon, sent a note early in the afternoon seeking parts of the trial transcript in which Douglas Faneuil, the former stockbroker's assistant, testified about his Dec. 27 phone calls to Ms. Stewart and her co-defendant and former Merrill Lynch stockbroker, Peter E. Bacanovic.

articles.abstract: The top executive of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's third-largest oil company, was forced to resign on Wednesday after an internal investigation into the company's surprise disclosure in January that it had overstated its oil and natural gas reserves by 20 percent.     The chairman of the company, Sir Philip Watts, stepped down less than a month after insisting that he would stay on despite a firestorm of criticism from investors over how the company handled the restatement.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cigarette Maker's Profit Rises
articles.snippet: The Gallaher Group, the maker of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, said profit rose 13 percent in the second half as it sold more cigarettes in Eastern Europe and in Ireland. Net income climbed to £145 million ($265 million) from £128 milli...
articles.abstract: The Gallaher Group, the maker of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, said profit rose 13 percent in the second half as it sold more cigarettes in Eastern Europe and in Ireland. Net income climbed to £145 million ($265 million) from £128 million a year earlier, according to Mark Rolfe, finance director of the company, which is based in Weybridge, England. Gallaher is trying to overcome falling consumption at home by expanding in countries like Russia and Kazakhstan, where some smokers are switching to Western brands. The acquisitions of Liggett-Ducat and Austria Tabak have also increased Gallaher's share of the Russian market.

articles.abstract: The Reuters Group, the world's largest publicly traded provider of financial information, named Niall FitzGerald as chairman to succeed Sir Christopher Hogg, who will retire. Mr. FitzGerald, 58, will take over from Sir Christopher, 67, on Oct. 1, Reuters said. Mr. FitzGerald has been on the board of Reuters since January 2003. He said last month he would retire as co-chairman of Unilever, the world's largest maker of food and soap, after 37 years at the company.

articles.abstract: The terrorism investigation code-named Mont Blanc began almost by accident in April 2002, when authorities intercepted a cellphone call that lasted less than a minute and involved not a single word of conversation.     Investigators, suspicious that the call was a signal between terrorists, followed the trail first to one terror suspect, then to others, and eventually to terror cells on three continents.

articles.snippet: Seeking to tap into the billions of dollars that Mexicans working in the United States send home each year, a Mexican mortgage finance company is opening a New York branch on Thursday to offer loans to Mexicans who want to buy a house in their cou...
articles.abstract: Seeking to tap into the billions of dollars that Mexicans working in the United States send home each year, a Mexican mortgage finance company is opening a New York branch on Thursday to offer loans to Mexicans who want to buy a house in their country.     Last year, Mexicans sent home $13.27 billion, more than the country earned from foreign tourism. The money lifts many families out of poverty and in some regions is the only source of income.

articles.headline: Bush Ad Campaign Ready to Kick Off An Expensive Effort
articles.snippet: The Bush campaign on Wednesday announced the start of what may be the most expensive advertising campaign in presidential history, with commercials devised to erase months of Democratic attacks by portraying President Bush as a plain-spoken leader...
articles.abstract: The Bush campaign on Wednesday announced the start of what may be the most expensive advertising campaign in presidential history, with commercials devised to erase months of Democratic attacks by portraying President Bush as a plain-spoken leader who steadied the nation after the 2001 terrorist attacks.    Bush campaign officials said their objective was for an upbeat, yet realistic feel-good depiction of the president. But the advertisements on Wednesday night drew criticism from some Democrats and the union representing firefighters, for, they said, exploiting tragedy in their stark use of imagery related to the Sept. 11 attacks. Three of the four commercials unveiled feature images of the smoldering and charred shell of the World Trade Center still standing; one also shows firefighters emerging from the wreckage carrying a stretcher draped with an American flag, presumably covering remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush campaign on Wednesday announced the start of what may be the most expensive advertising campaign in presidential history, with commercials devised to erase months of Democratic attacks by portraying President Bush as a plain-spoken leader who steadied the nation after the 2001 terrorist attacks.

articles.headline: Defied in Vote, Disney Leader Loses One Post
articles.snippet: In a remarkable vote of defiance against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company declined on Wednesday to support the re-election of Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive,...
articles.abstract: In a remarkable vote of defiance against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company declined on Wednesday to support the re-election of Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.    The mounting shareholder dissent prodded the board to strip Mr. Eisner of the chairman's title Wednesday night and give it to George J. Mitchell, Disney's presiding director and a former senator. Disney board members hope the split of the chairman and chief executive titles will pacify investors disgruntled about an underperforming stock price and Mr. Eisner's autocratic management style, according to three people close to the board's deliberations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a remarkable vote of defiance against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company declined on Wednesday to support the re-election of Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Engineer Sues Toshiba
articles.snippet: A former engineer at the Toshiba Corporation sued the company seeking 1 billion yen ($9 million) for his work in developing the flash memory chips that are widely used to store data and pictures in cellphones and digital cameras. The suit, which w...
articles.abstract: A former engineer at the Toshiba Corporation sued the company seeking 1 billion yen ($9 million) for his work in developing the flash memory chips that are widely used to store data and pictures in cellphones and digital cameras. The suit, which was filed in Tokyo District Court by Fujio Masuoka, who is now a professor at Tohoku University in Japan, is the latest in a series of claims on patent rights by Japanese corporate engineers seeking larger shares of the profits generated by their inventions. Last month, the same Tokyo court ordered the Nichia Corporation to pay 20 billion yen ($181.6 million) to the inventor of a blue-light-emitting diode, a widely used semiconductor device. A spokesman for Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, refused to comment on the latest legal action, saying that the company had not yet seen the lawsuit.   Todd Zaun (NYT)

articles.abstract: WHEN the Philadelphia Phillies' $458 million ballpark opens in April, some ticket holders may experience something akin to what Yogi Berra famously described as ''déjà vu all over again.''    While nothing could replicate the open-air spectacle of actually being there -- the crack of the bat, the cheering fans, the aroma of hot dogs and peanuts -- thousands of people toured the park, in a sense, long before it existed. They visited it virtually, gliding through a finely detailed, three-dimensional digital model.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Philadelphia Phillies' $458 million ballpark opens in April, some ticket holders may experience something akin to what Yogi Berra famously described as ''déjà vu all over again.''

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: G.M. To Buy Assembly Plant
articles.snippet: General Motors said it had offered to buy an assembly plant in India from the South Korean automaker, the Daewoo Corporation, to expand in the small-car market there. General Motors, which has less than 3 percent of India's vehicle market, said th...
articles.abstract: General Motors said it had offered to buy an assembly plant in India from the South Korean automaker, the Daewoo Corporation, to expand in the small-car market there. General Motors, which has less than 3 percent of India's vehicle market, said that it intended to acquire all the car-making assets of Daewoo, which is under bankruptcy protection, for undisclosed terms. The factory will help General Motors to double its sales and produce a new generation of cost-competitive vehicles, the company said. General Motors said it expected to roll out cars with the Chevrolet nameplate from Daewoo's assembly plant next year.   Saritha Rai (NYT)

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Use Fraud Tactic in Tax-Shelter Case
articles.snippet: A law firm that sold what the government says were abusive tax shelters participated in fraud and should not be allowed to hide the identities of its tax-shelter clients from the Internal Revenue Service, the Justice Department contends in court p...
articles.abstract: A law firm that sold what the government says were abusive tax shelters participated in fraud and should not be allowed to hide the identities of its tax-shelter clients from the Internal Revenue Service, the Justice Department contends in court papers.    In a significant increase in pressure on the law firm, Jenkens & Gilchrist, the government wants a court to suspend the normal confidentiality of communications between lawyers and their clients, contending that the firm engaged in perpetrating a fraud, not just giving legal advice. The so-called crime-fraud exception to attorney-client privilege is most often applied to lawyers who represent organized-crime families and drug rings suspected of racketeering, not to tax lawyers suspected of civil or criminal tax fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: A law firm that sold what the government says were abusive tax shelters participated in fraud and should not be allowed to hide the identities of its tax-shelter clients from the Internal Revenue Service, the Justice Department contends in court papers.
